article_title: Letta Government Is Only Latest to Exit Italy's Revolving Door
article_text:
If Matteo Renzi becomes Italy's new prime minister, he will lead the country's 62nd government since World War II and the fourth in little more than two years. If he were to survive the rest of the legislature—due to end in 2018— he would be one of the longest-serving premiers Italy has ever seen.

But Italy's history is stacked up against him. The country's revolving-door governments have long made its political system a punch line...

twitter.description: After 61 Italian postwar governments, history is against a long term for soon-to-depart Prime Minister Enrico Letta's probable successor, Matteo Renzi.
twitter.creator: @glegorano

image.alt: Letta government will be only the latest to exit Italy's revolving door.

article_summary:
The country's revolving-door governments have long made its political system a punch line...
If Matteo Renzi becomes Italy's new prime minister, he will lead the country's 62nd government since World War II and the fourth in little more than two years.
But Italy's history is stacked up against him.
If he were to survive the rest of the legislature—due to end in 2018— he would be one of the longest-serving premiers Italy has ever seen.
